awd_titl_txt: Lattice Field Theory and Hadronic Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is the theory of strong interactions between quarks and gluons that make up hadrons, such as protons and neutrons. This project will support theoretical and computational work to study the properties of this fundamental force at low temperatures, where quarks and gluons are bound together into hadrons, and high temperatures, where quarks and gluons interact weekly and form a quark-gluon plasma.  A post-doctoral fellow will be mentored by the PI to work on several aspects of the proposal. Numerical computations will use high-performance computing systems, and results obtained as part of this project will be presented at international conferences in nuclear and particle physics.

QCD belongs to a class of (QCD-like) theories that exhibit a transition from confinement (hadronic matter) at low temperature or density to asymptotic freedom (quark matter) at high temperature or density. This project will study the fundamental features of QCD-like theories by studying them at finite physical volume using a new global observable. The project will also study confinement by exploring the properties of certain hadronic matter called hybrid/exotic mesons that are unique to QCD-like theories. In addition, this study will address related topics such as the existence of tetraquarks. The grand canonical ensemble for QCD-like theories at finite density will be rewritten as a sum over canonical ensembles to study two-dimensional QCD. The lessons learned there will be used to explore the feasibility for studying four-dimensional QCD at finite density.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum Chromo Dynamics (QCD) is a theory of strong interactions and describes the binding of massless quarks and gluons (massless mediator of strong interactions) to form protons, neutrons, etc. It explains a wide range of experimental phenomena. Quark masses in the Standard Model of Fundamental Interactions is a part of weak interactions and is not present when QCD is studied in isolation. The remarkable feature of QCD is that a theory with no massless parameters (in fact, the theory has no free parameters) produces a rich spectrum of massive particles (protons, neutrons, etc). The scale invariance (no mass parameters) present at the classical level is dynamically broken at the quantum level.

Scale invariance in a classical theory of massless fermions (quarks) interacting with gauge fields (gluons) remains intact at the quantum level in some theories and is dynamically broken in some other theories. This feature is expected to be prevalent in a wide variety of theories not restricted to three space dimensions. A natural question for a theorist is: When does scale invariance remain intact and when is it dynamically broken? The specific objectives of this proposal was to provide some answers to this question by exploring a variety of theories in two space dimensions. Numerical analysis played a fundamental role in the projects peformed as part of this proposal and the PI trained post-doctoral fellows in relevant areas of theoretical nuclear physics.

Massless electrons interacting with photons restricted to two space dimensions  (Planar Quantum Electro Dynamics (PQED)) is not just a theoretical curiosity -- it is relevant in modern day condensed matter physics. Different PQED theories are characterized by the number of flavors of electrons. After performing a careful analysis of parity anomaly in such theories, the PI along with a post-doctoral fellow numerically inverstigated parity invariant PQED where the number of flavors of electrons had to be even. The outome of this numerical investigation clearly showed that all such PQED theories keep the scale invariance intact at the quantum level -- there are no massive bound states in any of these theories.

It was natural for the PI to extend the investigation to PQCD -- massless quarks interacting with gluons in two space dimensions. In addition to the number of quark flavors, the number of colors (a property of gluons) becomes a new parameter. The PI along with a post-doctoral fellow numerically investigated PQCD with two color degrees of freedom. The scale invariance remains intact at the quantum level only if the number of colors is larger than six. This places PQCD in a different class from PQED -- one can study the transition from theories that do not break scale invariance to theories that do.

The PI will continue to pursue investigation of scale invariance and dynamical scale breaking in the future by exploring connections with conformal field theories which are theories that have scale invariance at the quantum level. The PI will also explore mechanisms behind the dynamical breaking of scale invariance.
